research_programs.title: Research Program 1
research_programs.description:
Research
Molecular
Aging
Laboratory
The primary focus of my lab is to understand the molecular mechanisms that determine the longevity of an organism. The main interests of the lab are:
·
Diet-gene interactions that regulate longevity
·
Regulation of the Insulin-IGF-1 signaling pathway
·
Regulation of oogenesis and reproductive aging by nutrient-sensing pathways
·
The biology of Dietary restriction
·
Understanding molecular link between aging and innate immune pathways
·
Screening for novel compounds that extend longevity
We use a combination of molecular biology, genomics, Next Generation sequencing and molecular genetics approaches in the lab.
Caenorhabditis elegans
is the system of choice for our studies due to its short and reproducible life span, low maintenance cost, amenability to high throughput molecular techniques as well as ease of genetic manipulation. Interestingly, the molecular makeup of the innate immune response pathways and those that regulate longevity are strikingly similar between vertebrates and invertebrates. Such conservations are a key to extrapolating the results obtained in our model system and validating them in mammals.

publications.title: Methionine cycle in C. elegans serotonergic neurons regulates diet-dependent behaviour and longevity through neuron-gut signaling.
Kinome-wide RNAi screening in Caenorhabditis elegans reveals new modulators of insulin signaling and longevity.
Differential Transcriptional Landscape of Vero Cells During Dengue Virus 2 Infection in the Presence of Sinococuline.
A non-canonical role of somatic Cyclin D/CYD-1 in oogenesis and in maintenance of reproductive fidelity, dependent on the FOXO/DAF-16 activation state.
Diet-gene interactions ensure optimal life span and health.
DNA damage signals from somatic uterine tissue arrest oogenesis through activated DAF-16.
A localized hydrogel-mediated chemotherapy causes immunogenic cell death via activation of ceramide-mediated unfolded protein response.
Taurine deficiency as a driver of aging.
Protective Effects of Rifampicin and Its Analog Rifampicin Quinone in a Mouse Model of Obesity-Induced Type 2 Diabetes.
Adaptive capacity to dietary Vitamin B₁₂ levels is maintained by a gene-diet interaction that ensures optimal life span.
Transcriptome Analysis of Insulin Signaling-Associated Transcription Factors in C. elegans Reveal Their Genome-Wide Target Genes Specificity and Complexity.
CDX2 inducible microRNAs sustain colon cancer by targeting multiple DNA damage response pathway factors.
Alternative splicing of ceramide synthase 2 alters levels of specific ceramides and modulates cancer cell proliferation and migration in Luminal B breast cancer subtype.
Bile Acid Tethered Docetaxel-Based Nanomicelles Mitigate Tumor Progression through Epigenetic Changes.
The genetic paradigms of dietary restriction fail to extend life span in cep-1(gk138) mutant of C. elegans p53 due to possible background mutations.
Polyunsaturated fatty acids and p38-MAPK link metabolic reprogramming to cytoprotective gene expression during dietary restriction.
Dietary restriction improves proteostasis and increases life span through endoplasmic reticulum hormesis.
publications.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

publications.title: Using ChIP-Based Approaches to Characterize FOXO Recruitment to its Target Promoters.
A novel gene-diet pair modulates C. elegans aging.
Differential alternative splicing coupled to nonsense-mediated decay of mRNA ensures dietary restriction-induced longevity.
The global regulator Ncb2 escapes from the core promoter and impacts transcription in response to drug stress in Candida albicans.
Oxidative Homeostasis Regulates the Response to Reductive Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress through Translation Control.
A chromatin modifier integrates insulin/IGF-1 signalling and dietary restriction to regulate longevity.
Genome-wide endogenous DAF-16/FOXO recruitment dynamics during lowered insulin signalling in C. elegans.
Rifampicin reduces advanced glycation end products and activates DAF-16 to increase lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans.
PHA-4/FOXA-regulated microRNA feed forward loops during Caenorhabditis elegans dietary restriction.
A novel kinase regulates dietary restriction-mediated longevity in Caenorhabditis elegans.
Complex expression dynamics and robustness in C. elegans insulin networks.
A 286 bp upstream regulatory region of a rice anther-specific gene, OSIPP3, confers pollen-specific expression in Arabidopsis.
Integration of β-catenin, sirtuin, and FOXO signaling protects from mutant huntingtin toxicity.
publications.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience

publications.title: InAKTivation of insulin/IGF-1 signaling by dephosphorylation.
A PP2A regulatory subunit regulates C. elegans insulin/IGF-1 signaling by modulating AKT-1 phosphorylation.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) coupled to detection by quantitative real-time PCR to study transcription factor binding to DNA in Caenorhabditis elegans.
An endocytic pathway as a target of tubby for regulation of fat storage.
Reproduction and longevity: secrets revealed by C. elegans.
Worming pathways to and from DAF-16/FOXO.
A gene-centered C. elegans protein-DNA interaction network.
Identification of direct DAF-16 targets controlling longevity, metabolism and diapause by chromatin immunoprecipitation.
C. elegans tubby regulates life span and fat storage by two independent mechanisms.
JNK regulates lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans by modulating nuclear translocation of forkhead transcription factor/DAF-16.
publications.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
